Award.AwardTitle: Representation Theory and Harmonic Analysis on Homogeneous Spaces
Award.AbstractNarration:
The proposed research covers a broad spectrum of problems and ideas reaching from abstract harmonic analysis on symmetric spaces, geometry, and infinite dimensional analogues, to classical questions in abelian harmonic analysis. The basic subject of the proposed research is harmonic analysis on symmetric spaces G/H which connects analysis, group theory (symmetry) and geometry. The project includes holomorphic extension of H-spherical distributions, applications of intertwining operators and evaluations of their spectrum, analysis on infinite dimensional spaces, representation theory and G-invariant Banach spaces of functions. The physical parts include reflection positivity and transfer operators. This work combines methods and ideas from several areas of mathematics: complex analysis, group actions on complex manifolds, classical harmonic analysis, applied mathematics, and quantum ﬁeld theory.

Harmonic analysis and representation theory are two central subjects of mathematics and play an important role in pure and applied mathematics as well as theoretical physics. Well known examples of applications are tomography and signal analysis, but the proposed research deals with more abstract and fundamental questions. The proposal is related to several parts of mathematics, both pure and applied, and includes several connections to physics, in particular quantum field theory in form of reflection positivity, and applied sciences. The research involves wide spectrum of collaboration including graduate students and a network of other researchers in the USA, Mexico, and Europe.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Mathematics is abstract, based on concepts created by humans, but at the same time it generally useful and the language of science and engineering. Our work is centered around abstract harmonic analysis and its applications in the sciences. Our research is conducted in collaboration with researchers in the Europe, Mexico, and USA.

 

As a part of our educational and mentoring effort we involve our current and resent graduate students in our research and scientific work. This research is also present in graduate courses that we offer at LSU. Our grant has been used to support graduate student travel. That way our graduate student can observe first hand current research by leading experts, build up a research network, and meeting potential coworkers. 

 

Our research has been focused on a basic problem in constructive quantum field theory called reflection positivity. It builds a bridge from quantum mechanics to the more complicated quantum field theory where the two main resent revolutions in modern physics, relativity in form of gravitation and quantum mechanics meets. Here we use, and in fact develop, tools from representation theory, operator theory and abstract harmonic analysis to derive new results related to more than half a century old questions in physics.

 

The connection to applied mathematics is sampling and coorbit theory. Most sciences describe natural phenomenon through functions defined on Euclidean space or a manifold. But in real life we can only sample those functions through finite and discrete measurements. Sampling theory is the process of reconstruct the function from the discrete samples in an effective and economical way.

 

We, together with our coworkers, have obtained new results in complex analysis on bounded domains, in particular n-dimensional complex unit ball. This includes the description of the Bergman spaces through sampling as well as description of algebras of commuting Toeplitz operators using representation theory. The last mentioned result simplifies and generalizes previous know results considerably.

 

Geometry is one of the oldest subject in mathematics, going back to the work of the Greeks, in particular Euclid. This field was fundamentally changed through the work of Riemann and others creating non-Euclidean geometry, which then soon turned into differential geometry. Without those ideas there would be no general relativity. We are interested in the connection with group actions and how such an action with some restriction determines the manifold.  

 

Our physical space-time world is four-dimensional. But in physical considerations the number of interacting particles is unbounded leading to infinite dimensional analysis. We have obtained several new and interesting results in this subject including the determination of spherical representations of limits of classical compact symmetric spaces, Paley-Wiener type results and more.

 

The findings are reported in research publications, conferences, seminars, and workshops. Since the beginning of the grant we have published, including submitted and accepted articles, 29 research publications and presented our work 22 times. We have, together with several coworker, organized 10 workshops, conferences and special sessions to promote research in representation theory and harmonic analysis.
